title: Berlioz – Requiem, review: a brilliant recording of one of the grandest pieces ever written
text:
In 1837 that wild romantic Hector Berlioz was asked to compose a Mass for the dead, to mark the anniversary of the 1830 July Revolution. The result, performed in the huge space of Les Invalides in Paris, was one of the composer’s great successes – even though the conductor, an enemy of Berlioz’s, tried to ruin it by putting down his baton to take a pinch of snuff at a crucial moment.

The piece is one of the grandest ever written. It needs around 400 performers including 18 double-basses, two choirs, a tenor soloist, eight pairs of kettle-drums, four off-stage brass bands, and a fruity bass brass instrument called an ophicleide.

Berlioz’s imagination was stirred by the idea of making something...
